articles.headline: China Tells Businesses to Unionize
articles.snippet: Already facing rising labor costs, corporations doing business in China are now under a Sept. 30 deadline to let their workers unionize.
articles.abstract: Already facing rising labor costs, corporations doing business in China are now under a Sept. 30 deadline to let their workers unionize.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI  Some of the world’s biggest corporations are facing intense pressure from China to allow the state-approved union to form in their Chinese plants and offices. But many companies fear admitting the unions will give their Chinese employees the power to slow or disrupt their operations and will significantly increase the cost of doing business here.

articles.headline: Oil Companies Brace for a 2nd Blow
articles.snippet: For the second time in two weeks, a powerful hurricane is forcing oil companies to shut down major production and refining facilities.
articles.abstract: For the second time in two weeks, a powerful hurricane is forcing oil companies to shut down major production and refining facilities.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — For the second time in two weeks, a powerful hurricane is forcing oil companies to shut down major production and refining facilities, driving up gasoline prices in the United States even as the price of oil continues to slide on global markets.

articles.headline: Zimbabwe Rivals Strike a Bargain to Share Power
articles.snippet: It was unclear what a deal between the opposition leader Morgan Tsvangirai and President Robert Mugabe entails.
articles.abstract: It was unclear what a deal between the opposition leader Morgan Tsvangirai and President Robert Mugabe entails.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG  President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe and the opposition leader Morgan Tsvangirai struck a power-sharing deal on Thursday after more than a month of wrangling, but it was still far from clear how the bitter foes would divide the authority to govern.

articles.headline: Lehman’s Assurances Ring Hollow
articles.snippet: Lehman Brothers is in a similar position to the boy who cried wolf, except that its repeated denials of danger have damaged its credibility.
articles.abstract: Lehman Brothers is in a similar position to the boy who cried wolf, except that its repeated denials of danger have damaged its credibility.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is sad to watch Lehman Brothers, one of the grand old names of Wall Street and before that a cotton and coffee merchant from Alabama, struggling to avoid collapse.

articles.headline: Hedge Fund Glory Days Fading Fast
articles.snippet: Hedge funds are supposed to make money whether markets go up or down. But many of them are now being swept up in the turmoil in the financial world.
articles.abstract: Hedge funds are supposed to make money whether markets go up or down. But many of them are now being swept up in the turmoil in the financial world.
articles.lead_paragraph: Making millions  or even a few billion  by managing a hedge fund has been a running dream on Wall Street in recent years. But suddenly even the masters of this $2 trillion universe are falling on hard times, at least by their own gilded standards.

articles.headline: A West Bank Ruin, Reborn as a Peace Beacon
articles.snippet: A quiet revolution is stirring in Jenin, once a byword for the extremes of violence between Israelis and Palestinians.
articles.abstract: A quiet revolution is stirring in Jenin, once a byword for the extremes of violence between Israelis and Palestinians.
articles.lead_paragraph: JENIN, West Bank  Pessimism is a steady companion these days for advocates of Middle East peace. A lame-duck Israeli government is negotiating with a weak Palestinian leadership in the twilight of an unpopular American administration. Few forecast success.

articles.headline: Shares Continue Decline as Lehman Looks for Buyer
articles.snippet: As confidence in Lehman continued to drain away, the bank, one of the oldest names on Wall Street, continued to reach out to potential buyers, including Bank of America and Barclays.
articles.abstract: As confidence in Lehman continued to drain away, the bank, one of the oldest names on Wall Street, continued to reach out to potential buyers, including Bank of America and Barclays.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shares of Lehman Brothers continued to decline Friday as the beleaguered investment bank looked for a buyer even as the government indicated that it might not backstop the sale.
articles.byline: By Jenny Anderson, Andrew Ross Sorkin and Ben White

articles.headline: For Lehman Employees, the Collapse Is Personal
articles.snippet: In scenes reminiscent of the final days of Bear Stearns, employees at Lehman Brothers are watching the value of their stock evaporate and their job prospects dim.
articles.abstract: In scenes reminiscent of the final days of Bear Stearns, employees at Lehman Brothers are watching the value of their stock evaporate and their job prospects dim.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the last few days, employees of Lehman Brothers have wrung their hands as the value of their stock evaporated before their eyes. Now, many fear losing their jobs, too.
articles.byline: By Geraldine Fabrikant and Eric Dash

articles.headline: In First Big Interview, Palin Says, ‘I’m Ready’
articles.snippet: Sarah Palin said she agreed to John McCain’s offer without hesitation, perhaps her most confident answer in an interview that was at times tense and probing.
articles.abstract: Sarah Palin said she agreed to John McCain’s offer without hesitation, perhaps her most confident answer in an interview that was at times tense and probing.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the last two weeks, Democrats and even some Republicans have asked: Does Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska have enough experience to hold the second-highest office in the nation, or the presidency if the need arises?

articles.headline: Obama Plans Sharper Tone as Party Frets
articles.snippet: Senator Barack Obama is planning more forceful attacks as he confronts an invigorated G.O.P. ticket.
articles.abstract: Senator Barack Obama is planning more forceful attacks as he confronts an invigorated G.O.P. ticket.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator Barack Obama will intensify his assault against Senator John McCain, with new television advertisements and more forceful attacks by the candidate and surrogates beginning Friday morning, as he confronts an invigorated Republican presidential ticket and increasing nervousness in the Democratic ranks.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Investors Turn Gaze to A.I.G.
articles.snippet: Investors fear that the beleaguered insurance company will face billions in additional losses in the spreading credit crisis. On Friday, A.I.G.’s stock plunged almost 20 percent in early trading.
articles.abstract: Investors fear that the beleaguered insurance company will face billions in additional losses in the spreading credit crisis. On Friday, A.I.G.’s stock plunged almost 20 percent in early trading.
articles.lead_paragraph: Investors skittish about further losses in the financial industry have pounced on the American International Group, the beleaguered insurance company that has reported some of the biggest losses in the spreading credit crisis.
articles.byline: By Mary Williams Walsh and Jonathan D. Glater

articles.headline: Huge Storm Slams Into Coast of Texas
articles.snippet: Hurricane Ike made landfall at Galveston, Tex., as it threatened to devastate towns along the Gulf of Mexico with a wall of seawater 20 feet high.
articles.abstract: Hurricane Ike made landfall at Galveston, Tex., as it threatened to devastate towns along the Gulf of Mexico with a wall of seawater 20 feet high.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON  Hurricane Ike made landfall at Galveston, Tex., early Saturday as it threatened to devastate it and other towns along the Gulf of Mexico with a wall of seawater 20 feet high.
articles.byline: By James C. McKinley Jr. and Ian Urbina
